<Most of my play time is from Online, rather than single player>  Grand Theft Auto V is a brilliant game. It features seriousness and sillyness- ranging from a nice drive around the city to being carried in a limo by a helicopter to the top of the biggest mountain.  The missions and heists are a lot better when you are able to use voice communication, my crew and I use Skype every time we play and it makes everything nice and easy, with quicker response times by us.  There are a couple of bugs that I have noticed - objects popping into view just as you hit it, not being able to move after completing a mission / heist for a period of time, and randomly losing cars that you spent your hard earned (in game) cash on.  Overall, I would reccomend this game, whether you're a casual player or a try-hard.

Ive owned this game on two platforms. Recently i bought it again. This time during the summer sale.   First thing ill say is the multiplayer is rather grindy. Too have a really awesome car it will take a good 1-2 weeks or so (depending on if you wanna spend atleast 2+ whole days grinding missions and what car you are saving up for) for people with limited time to play. Although, you dont need these really fancy cars, helicopters, planes and now luxury yachts. A basic car, few weapons, abit of armour and friends can really bring out the best of what this game has to offer.  MONEY MAKING TIP: This wont make you money upfront but it can be worth it. Buy a CEO building maze bank being the cheapest (1mil). If playing solo grind these two missions in the 'CEO Work section'. Headhunter and sightseer. These missions are fairly easy. Especially if you have an Armoured Karuma or helicopter.  As a side note i really like how theyve made there servers. Having public lobby's, private lobby's (so on.) Theres nothing better than being in a public lobby and watching a truck being chased down by two turreted-limos! (and maybe a jet)  As for singleplayer, i think theyve done a good job developing the characters and then fitting their personalities into the game. The missions are fun, dont follow a predictable path and can be quite challenging at times. The story line can be short.   I would also like to point out that all the updates have been free. Stunt races free, heists free, all the updates and DLC has been free. No paid ones whatsoever.   NOTE:  Most of the reviews ive seen have been complaining about bans, or to be more detailed, false banning. If you encounter this issue (which i personally havent) I would suggest contacting Rockstar's support teams and resolving your issue. If you have been banned, its rather accidental (and therefore can be resolved). Or for a reason.

Pros: Graphics  7/10 Replayability money's worth  Physics are kinda realistic (Enjoy Hitting Someone with a car)  Very Immersive Open World (shoutout To LSPDFR as it renders you able to be a cop in singleplayer replayibility 10/10 headache seting up though)  Jobs are fun and action packed  Listen im mostly focused on GTA Online but Singleplayer has a great movie like story.  Cons: High Level players such as me have a sudden urge to drive like were having diarrhea in the car and kill random people like were on roids, Reason for this (for me) will be below  Online has a low P2W (Pay To Win) percentage being more consisted of LU2W (Level Up to Win)  Apparently random bans have been made often in this game but I have Not got one (Not really a con maybe people be mad cuz they be cheating cash?)  GOLDEN RULE>>>>>>> Money is easy to loss if your enjoying yourself, and making money is not balanced and more of a boring chore, making Heists the only valuable option.  BIG PROBLEM: People leave, disconnect or ♥♥♥♥ off of Heist session your in therefore rendering everthing useless and sending you back to the game lobby where you will wait 10 min to have a new pullout player again.  It becomes boring when you dont have money, most players at this point have rebelled and got Recovery Modded accounts or are enabling Godmode from their pc whatever it would be, rendering them Banned in the next patch or even sooner due to money spawning which is logged.  Overall a good Crimelife Simulator and Chill game to play with your main squad, 8.5/10

Saw this amazing Pie Recipe and thought I should share it!  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing

This may be the longest review I have ever typed out, but here goes nothing!  Wow, where do I even start with this masterpiece of a Grand Theft Auto game.. well for good measure I will break it out in seperate pieces.  : : : : : STORY : : : : : After just recently completing the story mode for a fourth time (Two times on PS3, once on PS4 and now on PC), and eventually will complete one last time, but with the mouse and keyboard. I am just so in love with the storyline for this game, it is so well-acted and I wouldn't really say well-written since this is just a simple plot, but still though it's a really awesome storyline for such a quality Grand Theft Auto game. From the main characters to the secondary and minor characters, (Haven't met all of them, but met a great bunch of them) all of them are just very loveable characters, I love all of them, but the one that stays in my heart will always be Michael, he's now my number two protagonist in GTA, number one will be Niko Bellic from IV, don't get me wrong, but Niko has a much better storyline that's connected to him. I love this storyline so much..  : : : : : GAMEPLAY : : : : : Rockstar really changed up the gameplay from GTA IV, alot of nice improvements and changes, with the First Person perspective added in with the PS4 and Xbone versions at the time, it really does bring in the immersive feel of the beautiful map of this game. With them raising the framerate to 60FPS, It is so much more smoother and it brings in the immersive feel of the game so much more than it was on the PS3 and the PS4. I really love all of the weapons, but I wish to see some more unique weapons aswell, such as the Musket and the Rail Gun and a couple more. All of the types of vehicles in this game, there's alot of vehicles.. I wish they brought back the PMP 600 from IV.. That car was beast.. Please Rockstar, bring it back? <3  : : : : : GRAPHICS AND PORT : : : : : The first time I believe I ever talk about how the game looks.. So, of course the game looks abso-lutely stunning at all angles (I was playing through the game and playing Online on High, eventually will be max settings and will beat the story, again.. lol) The draw distance is awesome and it feels much more immersive than ever since it's running at 60FPS.. which brings me down to breaking down the port of this magnificent game. Rockstar, I was unsure of what you were going to do for this port at first, but then since you guys took extra time to polish it and everything, of course I got a little impatient, but I was trusting you, and look at what you did.. You did an outstanding job with bringing this, yet I say again, masterpiece to PC. Thank you for upgrading to 60FPS, since it is necessary for a GTA PC port which helps to bring in the immersion to playing in a GTA game. Of course, it's not perfect, I tend to have little drops here and there, but it's so much more smoother now..  : : : : : GTA ONLINE : : : : : I love playing Online so much, it is so much more expanded than GTA IV's, of course.. I have to admit, I was really impatient for waiting for Heists, but I got through it, When I saw the trailer, I was so ready to play Heists. But let's face it, Heists are just ONE big thing to do in GTA Online, but honestly, there are limitless things you can do in GTA Online, and now you can record it with the Rockstar Editor! You can make AWESOME movies! If there's nothing to do.. that what are you thinking about then? Hm? You just have to be creative and think of all of the awesome gameplay features, the vehicles, everything Rockstar has incorporated into this game.. Like I said before.. limitless things you can do!!!  : : : : : CONCLUSION : : : : : I believe I have covered everything as possible, so here is my last and final statement about this game. Rockstar has done an outstanding job with the game by itself, incorporated more amazing stuff in their DLCs, bringing us unlimited things to do in GTA Online, it looks mind-blowingly amazing and feels so much better due to a higher framerate, Of course, look at this review, that's alot of words saying that I love this game, but I could go on forever and EVER talking about how great this game is.. Only thing I will say of what you should play on to enjoy it the most on, is definitely the PC version, Rockstar my last words to you, is this, Thank you so much for treating this masterpiece right on PC, and you have stole my heart for making such an incredible Grand Theft Auto game.. I can't wait to see what you establish in GTA VI, here's hoping it's in Vice City!  RATING: 10/10, I would want to go higher.. screw it.. 999,999,999,999,999/10  Last words: In regardless of how much it is, I would reccomend getting it on a sale if you have played it before, but if it is going to be your first time playing it, it is worth full-price (in my opinion), but, do what you want, you won't be mistaken. Also, I have crashed on this game in the beginning, but I have found a solution from someone and solved it, if you guys are crashing and don't know what to do, check if you have a plsapp64.dll in C:\Windows\System32, get rid of it, it solved my crashing and it should solve yours.

Grand Theft Auto is the best and fastest selling game of all time. That is actual fact. This game has broken world records for a reason.  Those parts aside let me give you my experience with the game. I played the original GTA V on Xbox 360 the day it came out, and followed up playing GTA Online when it was released later. Both games (might as well be two seperate games) are fantastic. The Story mode is rich with excellent dialogue and amazing characters, you never know what you will hear next or what might happen. This is a game of satire, if satire is something you are not a fan of or hate crude and vulgur humor this game will never sit well with you. If you are okay with satire prepare for it to be cranked up to 11 as this is the biggest amount of satirical humor you can find. No one is safe from Rockstars plethora of jokes and jabs.  The actual game play itself is beyond solid, compared to the original GTA IV made on the same engine 7 years ago, this game stands tall. The driving is a tiny bit arcady but it is much more realistic and responsive than the sluggish and oil slicked tires of GTA IV driving. Shooting is much more solid as well, targets snap to much more fluidly with more precise control on where you wish to aim as opposed to GTA IVs snap and spastic dragging of the reticule back to the center of mass.  Flying is also solid and even much better than it has ever been before, vehicles feel like they have weight to them while flying and take realistic damage. Specific parts of vehicles or aircraft can be targeted to cause precision damage, such as shooting off the rotors of helicopters or taking out the engine of a jet. Speaking of flying, there is turbulence now that is reduced by your flying skill which gives incentive to level it as well as enjoy the more responsive flying style, planes can even stall if they fly straight up.  Customization in this game is huge, each character can wear a vast array of clothing and haircut or tattoo options and every vehicle can be customized with unique colors. Compared to GTA IV it's laughable how drastic the difference. In GTA IV you couldn't even customize cars, you could get their color changed but it would be randomized what color you got so you had to repeat the process needless and there was nothing else. That's it. GTA V has options a plenty, from performance enchancing to many cosmetic changes as well as protective such as armor and bulletproof tires.  Overall Single Player for GTA V is an amazing experience, and with the new first person mode, replaying the campaign and just using FPM is an entirely different experience. GTA Online is vast environment with so much content that I can't even cover everything I want to say about it here, if you are truly interested in GTA Online go check out my guide 'Duo Vandal's Ultimate Guide to GTA Online' on the Guide section and give it a rating if you enjoyed it. I've been playing GTA Online to this day since 2013 and it's the best Online experience you can have.

Well, there it is: the greatly anticipated, three-times-delayed 'port' of GTA V for PC. After a 2 hour (59GB) download and a 15 minute unencrypting/preallocating/unpacking session on one of the fastest SSDs out there at the moment, everything went smooth from thereon and I was ready to jump into the game (at 1AM). After doing a couple of missions in the single player and familiarizing myself with the controls (which are really smooth, except for when flying a plane...), I decided to check out GTA Online...  8 hours later, I noticed it was 9 o'clock in the morning and I had to already have been in the office... Obivously I 'worked at home' that day, as this is honestly one of the most addicting games I've played in a long while! As anyone probably knows already, and as anyone can tell from all the other reviews, this is definitely a game to get! I'd like to add some negative points to this review section however. Some of them might be fixed in the future, and all of them should definitely not withold you from buying the game, but it's good to know there are still some issues with this game.   One of the few negative things I can say about this game right now, is that GTA Online sometimes literally takes 3-4 minutes to load up, and this 'loading period' also happens when you disconnect from a job (or get kicked from it, or failed to connect to it...). It also seems the game stops loading (or loads terribly slowly) when you ALT-TAB out of the game during the loading screen (I like to do this and do something else while the game loads), so you really have to be on the loading screen for it to continue loading. I've missed out the start of a job (and thus got disconnected) because I ALT-TABbed to desktop for ~30 secs while joining a heist... When I tabbed back to the game, the heist had already started without me (as my friend, who was also in this heist, told me) and I was stuck on an infinite loading screen that I could not get out of.  Also, joining another player's session can sometimes take very long. When there is no free slot in that session, you'll be asked to be placed in a queue, but this doesn't work very often either. Somehow, I've ended up singing in the shower more times than actually getting in the game with my friends when I clicked 'Join Game'.   Other minor bugs I noticed: when browsing the web (on your virtual smartphone) and clicking on a video, the video will indefinitely play and you cannot close the browser anymore, thus resulting in you having to ALT-F4 out of the game. Furthermore, flying a plane feels really wonky (aside from the turbulence, which also adds an extra difficulty factor). The plane tends to nose-dive and you seem to have to correct this continuously by pressing numpad-5 (nose up).   Other than that, this is an  amazing  game, because once you're in with your friends, all the loading time was well worth it, and I cannot think of any other multiplayer game out there right now that is this much fun to play.

If you're looking for an enjoyable experience in an open world both singleplayer and multiplayer and enjoy grinding for luxuries it would be well worth taking a look at GTA V.

Growing up, the GTA series were one of my favorite video games. Unfortunately, it did not stick around since the only time I could have played GTA was during summers. When I heard GTA V was going to come out, I was not as excited as I should have been. I wasn't hyped. I did not pay attention to their announcements or newsfeed for this upcoming release. This also had to do with how Rockstar refused to release it for PC till 2 years after it's been released on consoles. Anyhow, even knowing that I wasn't excited for the release of the PC version for this game, I went ahead and purchased it seeing that many of my friends bought it. In all honesty, it's a great game and I've been addited to it for the first 3 weeks. Eventually, my enjoyment for this game died down. GTA V Online is a sandbox game, but it does lack things to do. Plus, the hackers/scripters/modders did not help sustain the satisfaction. They actually destroyed it. From my previous experiences in GTA games, I've known that this game had cheats, so it wasn't a surprise. I did not play the campaign, but I'm going to recommend this game and it has definitely paid off my $60.

Despite its’ predecessor being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port of a console game, this game has fared very well. If you don’t know yet, Grand Theft Auto V is pretty much the best game for any person (with friends) to have fun, either online or not.   Single player: Grand Theft Auto V’s single player has its’ flaws, but I still though that it was a lot better than Grand Theft Auto IVs story. Unfortunately Rockstar doesn’t update it as much as it does on Online, so this game is more centered towards those who enjoy online. Despite that, the single player is infinitely fun, and definitely a time waster, that coupled with mods is an amazing combination.   Online: Now, obviously every online game has its’ hackers and its’ cancerous players, so playing online with random players is going to be very hard. Seeing as many of the online players are either ♥♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, trollers, or 12 year olds, it’s pretty hard to have any fun or make any friends online. The online portion gives you a lot of opportunity and a lot of jobs to do, but then again you must have friends. You could own a company, so you could be your very own Fatcat, you can also own an MC and be your own president, and with that comes many other jobs and missions. Heists are very fun, but hard to play with randoms because I’m pretty sure there’s some quantum physics law that says one of the randoms has to be either ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, or with a bad internet connection, because it’s absolutely impossible to be stable while on random. It’s impossible to play more than one heist, even if you’re lucky to play one, with randoms. So unless you have dedicated friends, it’ll be very hard for you to enjoy this game.   Conclusion: Amazing game to play with friends. I recommend this to anyone with some extra cash and a semi beefy computer. P.S. If you’re cool you’re invited to add me and play if you want!

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

BEST GAME EVER!!!   Pros;  + Stunning visuals & graphics + Almost everything feels real (object detail, shadows, effects, etc) + Every characters feels unique (great voice actors, realistic character details) + 3 main characters with different personality, skills, unique vehicles and background + Even NPC feels real (can call cops at you, can chat with you even fight at you if provoked) + Many kinds of animals that can be threat + Playing the game with FPS mode feels different + The land, sea and air is exploreable with realistic means + Huge diversity of vehicles (car (you can pimp most of them), bikes, planes, boats, heli, minisub, military vehicles) + Many weapons types, variant and modifications to choose for  + Great story + Cops more active and cunning to track you down + In-game money feels precious, not easy to earned and can be spend out quickly + Tons of things to do (side missions, collectibles, achievements, explorations) + the game is huge improvement from the prequel (more optimized with current hardware and software) + GTA online and online heist fiture (haven't try it myself yet)  Cons; - 60GB game size is kinda take a lot of time to download - In-game benchmark tools have some issues (not just me) - Long loading time (using SSD or SSHD may improve loading time) - Vram hungry games, if you want to play it with higher graphics settings, antialiasing and resolutions - 50 bucks for the game is worth it, but not everyone is willing to pay that much (a discount gonna be nice)  Conclusions;  Just buy the game and play it till you bored with it (i'm bored)

There are times when I look at Los Santos and think 'why would you even think to build that?' This is, appropriately, a thought that I often have about Los Angeles. In GTA 5's case, the tone is different: baffled wonderment as opposed to baffled, y'know, despair. Rockstar have created one of the most extraordinary game environments you will ever visit. I look at it and I wonder at the vast expense of effort required to render every trash bag in every back alley just so. I marvel at the care evident in San Andreas' gorgeous sunsets, in the way that sunglasses subtly alter the colour balance of the world, in the artfully-chosen selection of licensed music designed to accompany your experience. Everything about Los Santos demonstrates the extraordinary amount of thought and love poured into it by hundreds of developers over many years. The abiding irony of Grand Theft Auto 5 is that everybody who actually lives in Los Santos hates it there.  This is the most beautiful, expansive and generous GTA game and also, by some distance, the nastiest and most nihilistic. Rockstar went through a phase, in Bully, Grand Theft Auto IV and the sadly console-bound Red Dead Redemption, of framing their protagonists as anti-heroes. GTA 4's Niko Bellic did some terrible things, but he had a downtrodden charm that helped you like him as you piloted him through the underworld. He was surrounded by people who were larger-than-life but ultimately, beneath the surface, people. Among those people were some of Rockstar's better female characters—Kate McReary, Mallorie Bardas, The Lost and Damned's Ash Butler.  GTA V Argument  Grand Theft Auto 5 does away with all of that, deliberately but to its detriment. Its trio of protagonists occupy a city full of vapid, two-dimensional caricatures, and they flirt with that boundary themselves. Michael is a middle-aged former bankrobber, unhappily married and on the edge of a breakdown. Franklin is a young hood, purportedly principled but willing to do almost anything for money. Trevor is a desert-dwelling, meth-dealing psychopath with a homebrew morality that sits uneasily alongside his capacity for violent cruelty and sexual aggression. The campaign explores their relationship through a series of heists and misadventures as they clash with every L.A. stereotype you might imagine—the bored Beverly Hills housewife, the corrupt fed, the bottom-rung fraudster, the smug technology exec, and so on.  Against this backdrop, it's only Michael, Franklin and Trevor that appear to have any kind of internal life. I get the impression that this is deliberate, part of the game's relentless skewering of southern California and indicative of Rockstar's waning interest in romantic anti-heroes. Trevor's introduction, in particular, amounts to a particularly explicit '♥♥♥♥ you' to the characters and themes of Grand Theft Auto IV. GTA 5 is heartless in that way, and as a result I found the narrative difficult to care about. It is ambitious, well-performed, and the production values are extraordinary—but it is also derivative and brutishly adolescent, set in a world where the line between criminality and the rule of law is blurry but where it is always hilarious that somebody might be gay.  GTA V Chinatown  It's an R-rated episode of The A-Team where the 'A' stands for '♥♥♥♥♥♥♥'. The campaign's best moments come when your cigar-chomping master strategist, insane former military pilot and talented driver come together, and when you're given the power to choose how to use each of them. These heists are set-piece missions where you pick an approach and perform set-up tasks in the open world before setting out on the job itself. In the best of them, which occur later in the campaign, it really does evoke the satisfaction of having a plan come together. Perhaps you position Trevor on the high-ground with a rocket launcher, Michael on foot with a stealth approach, and Franklin in an armoured ram-raider. With a button press you can flick between the three, dynamically orchestrating a crime caper on your own terms.  It is also in these moments that Rockstar's most ambitious storytelling takes place. Your choice of character, crew, and even certain in-game actions have subtle effects on the dialogue. In an early heist, a crewmember dropped part of the score but, as Franklin, I was able to retrieve it—a side-objective that I'd set for myself but that was subsequently reflected in a later conversation between him and Michael. This is another example of Rockstar's extraordinary attention to detail, and if the rest of the campaign respected your agency in this way it might overcome its weaker moments.  GTA V Plane Chase  As it is this is a very long game with a lot of filler. There's much driving from A to B, a lot of conversations in cars, a lot of gunfights with hordes of goons who show up just to run into your gunsights over and over. It's far richer in set-piece moments than its predecessor—drug trips, aerial heists, dramatic chases—and many of these look incredible even if they're light on actual interaction. In the best examples, you soak in the atmosphere and happily ignore the fact that you're only really being asked to follow the on-screen instructions. In the worst examples—insta-fail stealth sequences, sniper missions and so on—it's harder to ignore the shackles that are placed on the player in order to preserve the game's cinematic look and feel.  I spent a lot of my time with the campaign frustrated along these lines, bored of the same mission templates that I've been playing through since GTA III and making the most of the scant opportunities to play my own way, like Franklin's refreshingly open assassination missions. Then, inevitably, I'd be doing one of those rote activities—a heavily scripted freeway chase, perhaps—when the magic of that extraordinary world would creep up on me again. It'd hit me: I'm doing 150 km/h along the Pacific Coast Highway at sunset. The rock station is playing 30 Days In The Hole by Humble Pie. It feels incredible, a collision of pop-culture, atmosphere, music and play that is unique to GTA.

Here's the thing. The method currently being used to mod isn't really what most people think of as modding. ScriptHook, is an example of DLL Assembly Code Injection, which sneaks foreign code into the process in order to provide a method for an additional payload of code to hook/modify the game process in memory.  The problem with this is that there is no way to tell what the payload is. Nor is there anyway to prevent the payload from working in only some areas of the game.  That's the point a lot of people don't understand here, we're not talking addons. We're talking DLL files that have been modified to allow a user to run ANY additional code they want and have the game accept it and execute it. There are no limits to what can be run with this and the trainer that comes as the included demonstration of scripthook is a very benign usage of the potential.  To give you an example of the dangers of allowing DLL Injected clients to connect to multiplayer servers or any other client for that matter, until recently, in Reign of Kings, hackers using the same method that scripthook uses, were using injected assembly code into DLLs to modify files on the computers of other players on the servers they connected to and in many cases, even the files on the servers themselves.  When we're talking about DLL Injection, there is no such thing as singleplayer mod or multiplayer mod. It's just foreign code being run, anywhere the user wants. The only way to prevent it is to check the integrity of the DLLs of any client on connection and cutting the connection as soon as a disprecency is found. It may seem like overkill, but the alternative is a complete loss of security for anyone using gta online.

Honestly, disregard the negative reviews...People zero-bombing a game because of a launch bug where they couldn’t play online right out the gate...Let's get one thing straight...for ANY game releasing to PC that is online, expect to no be able to reach servers the first 10-45 mins because of the HUGE overflow of players trying to do the same thing you are...That is not a reason to down vote a game because you couldn’t go online instantly.   *GAME REVIEW* This game is an amazing port. WAY better than GTA 4. The gameplay is clear, smooth, and pretty much flawless with updated drivers. Single player is the same as next gen, but way more detailed. There is so much more detail in the world around you. The textures, shadows, and sun shafts are simply jaw-dropping. If you have a good gaming computer, buy this NOW. If you don’t, stay with console, otherwise you will end up like the other negative reviewers.  *END GAME REVIEW*  Another thing about people complaining about the 'unpacking'...I don’t know what you're talking about. I didn't have to wait for an “unpack” at all. I literally preloaded, downloaded the patch that dropped release hour, and hit play and it worked. I guess for the people giving 'Pissy Reviews' on the unpacking, get a better HDD/SSD and CPU and quit your complaining.  For the people saying 'The game isn’t launching.' or, 'OMG i have LONG load times'...once again, get a better computer. Don't complain about load times when you're playing on an $800 or less 'Gaming' computer. My load times were a minute tops to get into single player and about 2-3 mins to find a populated lobby.   For the people complaining about the Social Club, just...shut your mouth...it's Rockstar, they are a Company, aka business, that is here to make money. Just like every other company you get mad at because you have to use their launchers or interfaces to play their games, they are businesses there to make money. Plain and simple. I've never been enamoured by the general theme of GTA - carjacking, murder, prostitution, racketeering, etc. - but the open world and play options make it a must buy. I think GTA V is the best so far as there's so much going on you can easily become hooked and totally immersed. The missions are good and choice of weapons excellent. Often I find it satisfying just to wander about, ride some bikes, drive cars and ride on the train shooting up whatever takes my fancy and have the cops pursue me. Talking of which, the police AI is a bit samey and could do with a fix with some variation in future GTA games.  Playing on max graphic level the visuals are fantastic with amazing attention to detail - this is what really makes it for me but then I'm a bit of a recluse and like to completely escape into a different environment for a while. The sea has realistic waves and swell, the landscapes are interesting and the city buzzes with activity.   I don't play online (tried once, too many idiots ruining it) but some folks rave about it. There seems to be an issue with using mods and being banned by Rockstar I understand, but if you're content to play the game as is you won't have a problem.   Two minor downers for me are 1/ the ludicrous helicopter flight. The machine is all over the place, rolling and swaying like it's on a rubber band; and 2/ the driving position inside many of the cars is like being a dwarf because you can barely see over the dash/steering wheel. Who's responsible for this? Have they ever driven a motor vehicle?  There are some fun cheats you can employ which enable you to get into places that attract wanted levels but I started doing this only after twice finishing the game. It has a variable ending depending on choices you make. The game is a bit pricey but compared with many others I think it's worth it for the amount of interactive fun you can have doing anything.

Ignoring all the recent Steam Summer Sale business for people who weren't able to preorder the game, and they could get a bit of the same edge as people who did preorder.  Now I understand sixty bucks isn't that much hard to come by.  Is GTA5 fun? In most cases, I like to drive down a ♥♥♥♥ing mountain in my sports car and still make it without it exploding on me. I could go past a mountain to catch up to my teammates when I was away for a while. I could play golf and tennis. I could scubadive, I could find there's no easy mode to fly a plane in this game like it is in other games, which creates a sense of realism to it.  Pros: Had the highest hype train in 2015 Variable third and first person views, which most games don't have. Beautiful illustration of graphics A rather curious wellput storyline, always noting to you that in every GTA game, there's always a betrayal, which competitors don't really do, such as Saints Row GTAOnline feels realistic about a town riddled with crime and chaos, it's City Survival Simulator, technically. Although no one's trying to survive, but it gives you a frantic case of a city sprawling with gangs  But as with every game, there are cons  Cons: Money isn't easily made unless it's by stocks and doing a heist as Michael. When the player is given about 7.5K in cash, their instinct is to see what they can do with the amount of money they have compared to Franklin GTAOnline is riddled with cheaters and trainers at the moment, where even a newly made friend can be a hacker that has a mini-SMG that shoots out 40k bags of cash, just to get your attention and telling you to take it. Playerbase is unusually aggressive, but then comes a wise choice of pick your crew and group carefully, as even your own teammates can turn on you, simply for being in the same limo. Those cheaters and trainers? They get RP and cash boosts and what not. They also occasionally have the ability to drop a nuke in Los Santos and murder them while pinning someone else for the blame.  Regardless to say, though. I still personally prefer to play the game every now and then. Although what I'm spouting for the most part is blasphemy, this is still just my opinion of the game. I'm not a professional critic, after all.

Short v.: Campaign: a blast Multiplayer: Playerbase is about 25% Hackers/Cheaters  Campaign:  Love it. Well developed story line, funny charactors, and great graphics. The ganes doesn't fail to express how large the map is. Flying and driving taken to another level. Now I see why it was needed to add planes to the large list of player controlable vehicals. 10/10  Multiplayer: Another work of art, but not as flawless. Leveling takes time, but not too much time. Higher level stuff requires better performance for more cash. But with Shark cards they threw that out the window. As long as you can't buy ranks from them the game will keep you occupied even if you have a large wallet. A large problem that as of now (5/31/15) there is an outrageous amount of hacks being used (traininers, cheat engine, DLL injectors, Process Memory Edits, ect.) Every other session I join has a hacker. Mostly them either blowing you up every sec, making you commit suicide, or spamming bags of money over your head. Though this can ruin the experience for most people, if you find 3 friends to do all the heists with you will be fine. GETTING MONEY FROM HACKERS WILL NOT GET YOU BANNED. 5/10 (R* needs help with anticheat or turn on VAC for ffs.)

DISCLAIMER - This review is based upon my experiences so far within GTA 5 and online.  So, I bought GTA 5 and online for the pre-purchase bundle. I downloaded it and got into it quite easily. The difficulty level ramps up a little after the first series of missions in single player, but one you 'get' it, you'll find it quite easy. The sandbox setting is amazing, and the little details and stuff that have gone into the singleplayer world are excellent. The Single player is too short though.   Online The online game is moderate fun. Although the map is fully visible. Unlocking weapons, cars and so forth is a lot of fun, and its not really a grind. However, there are hackers, and yes they will kill you from over the map, they can spawn in anything, from harriers to asteroids. People will troll you if you try and do objectives. However, the multiplayer element is really interesting. The bounty system is fun. However, heists are almost impossible to get into as a beginner, because people WILL kick you without explanation. I say....6/10.   EDIT:  Free-event mode. Or, a waste of an update. So, GTA got a new update, with new events occuring every 15 minutes, they can be the mundane, from pulling wheelies and flying close to the ground, to the werewolf event (Hunted) and speed. However, the interesting events don't happen often, it takes just 1 or 2 people working together to block everyone else, and its just not varied enough.  I will recommend this game to anyone who enjoys multiplayer. For a better Singleplayer experience, I would personally go to either Saints row 2 and 3, or GTA 3 and 4.

I won't lie, GTA V is a superb game! The singleplayer has definitely been one of the best experiences I have ever had in gaming. Its literally jaw dropping to see how much detail there is in Los Santos. It feels like a living and breathing city! I really liked the story and cared about all three characters when times got tough for them. The online component is also very good, with loads of heists, races and other missions to play with your friends. Be warned though, since the game uses matchmaking, you will have quite a few connectivity issues. Also, you cannot deny that there is a giant amount of hackers in the game. It won't be a problem if you just prefer friend only sessions so you can play with your friends, but you will definitely suffer if you want to play with random people. Overall, I must say I had tons of fun with this game, so I can't not recommend it. You might want to wait until Rockstar actually takes the hacker problem a little more seriously, however.

After putting a fair few hours into this title and being new to the franchise, I have decided to give my verdict.  I love this game. I have had great fun on both the online platform and the single player. GTA 5 online is excellent fun with a group of buddies while completing heists or just generally arsing around. The single player is both engaging and tells an exellent and involving story. Both modes are beautiful by day and night and the port from console is un-noticable.  HEISTS - are great fun with friends and are challenging when its needed. The hollywood action movie vibe is very well recieved and makes for a great experience WHEN IT WORKS.   HOWEVER The online matchmaking systems and navigation leave A LOT to be desired. Matchmaking is slow beyond function and there is very little options at the menu when starting up the online mode. More often than not, it wil fail to join a session and throw me into single player. From here, you will find a much better menu that lets you choose the type of lobby you wish to join.  Waiting for players in heists takes atleast ten minutes MINIMUM which is outright unacceptable when there are still hundreds of thousands of people playing at any given time  sort all of this out and you have the recipe for a great game!
I recommend this game, Since, in my opinion, it´s one of the best games currently in existence.  Also, very well optimized.

So far so good, spent 92 minutes 'playing' GTA 5, by playing if that includes staring at a loading screen then I'm currently having a grand old time.    --------------------------------------------------  *** UPADTE 25.04.2015 **  Following the recent patches I can now finally play the game, and can say that a really nice job has been done by Rockstar, I also own this on both 360 and PS4, and without a doubt I love playing this with mouse & k/b and at 2560x1440   I had quite a rocky start to getting this game working, and it would also seem that not as many people had the same issue as me with getting the game up and running, as I couldn't initially even get to the calibration screen yet alone the game.  Now that it works, I'm really enjoying the game, the graphics are nice, with a high res monitor they look amazing, with everything maxed I've not hit any framerate issues yet, and that's on a 4gb GTX 680.  On a first impressions basis I'd say that this is where GTA belongs, if you don't have a console version, then it's worth getting on the PC, if you do have a console version, there's some improvements over those ports but you'd have to ask yourself is having 60fps, higher res and the Movie Editor enough to make you shell out for another copy.  Control wise personally for me you can't beat the good old k/b and mouse, I've had a few adjustments to make with the driving sections as I do miss the refined movements you get with the analogue sticks on a joypad, but that's a small price to pay in order to enjoy the game on the pc. You can play using both JP and K/B & Mouse, which can in some respects make the driving sections easier.  Overall it's a good game, worth getting if you don't have it and like the GTA series, I don't think you're going to find massive innovations based on the previous game, but it's a GTA game and it delivers on the parts that you want it to.

I dont even think I could touch the console version again.

An excellent addition to the GTA series. As always Rockstar up the bar yet again from the previous titles.  Pro's  * 3 protagansists. A welcome change from the single character of previous versions. It adds a whole new depth and the fact you can swap between them seemlessly is excellent * Graphics - Incredible as always * Open sandbox world - Living, breathing world which would take hours to run around the entire map. * Story - Great story with some incredibly funy moments * Variety of things to do. Gym, Saloons, Tennis, clothes shops, golf, flying lessons, shooting ranges etc. etc. There's hundreds of things to do and explore outside of the main and side missions. * Inclusion of a first person mode. Didn't use it myself, but will do on a replay as it'll change the dynamics of the game.  Cons  * This is more of a gripe with all GTA games. There's no consequence if you simply escape the sirens. There needs to be an element of getting caught afterwards. I.e. someone takes a picture of you and you're a wanted person if you go on an insane rampage and get to 5*. I would recommend this is purely a hardcore thing, but still would add alot of depth to the game.  * More awareness from cops. I just jumped a red light? you're OK with that? great...    I know there's some gripes about the cost. But to be fair, it's not worth 'not recommending' this over that. You'd miss out on 50+ hours of fun.

I'll brake this review down into Singleplayer mode and GTA Online. But first, let me just say ♥♥♥♥ you to the R* for ripping people off on the summer sale. That was ♥♥♥♥ing cheap.  Now to the review.  Singleplayer mode: The storyline is quite interesting at most points. Each character has been written quite well. The heists are fun and more often than not, heart-racing (if you're like me and ♥♥♥♥ing panic in every possible video game situation involving shooting.) After you've completed the storyline, you could head down and play some golf with yourself or tennis with Michael's Wife* (maybe.) Additionally, you can complete all those strangers and freaks missions that have, which I'm pretty sure, mentally disabled people. Some of them are seriously sick ♥♥♥♥s. Like Trevor. Even before you finish the storyline, I spent 1 hour when I first had access to Franklin, just exploring the map. Performing stunt jumps etc.   GTA Online: Hackers. Hackers everywhere. As a lot a lot a LOT of people know, R* isn't doing ♥♥♥♥ about the hackers. Sure at most they've probably banned 1/10 of them. They can make the game not very fun. However, there is an option. If you have friends or a crew or whatnot, you can just head into a private session with them and play there. Because chances are you're playing like that because you don't want to go head to head with a hacker or something. Adding to that, you can also do solo-mode which is almost like Storymode, except you play on your own character and have more limited things as to what you can do.  Overall, I would say for GTA Online: 3/5 stars. Mainly because there are some glitches and stuttering as well as hackers. For GTA 5: 4/5 stars. It was pretty great, although I did encounter issues with freezes etc.  So that's 7/10. Not bad, pretty good, but also not execellent. Anyways, blah.

'Obvious Console Port'  I wanted this game to live up to the hype; in some way its does, but major issues exist.  Pros: - it was finally released on PC? - largeish sandbox area to explore, or is it? Somehow it feels smaller than the San Andreas title's map. - there are no locked areas; you can drive around immediately (compare to Vice City's locked bridges)  Cons: - joystick support (which worked in Vice City) is lacking, and the keyboard+mouse controls make attacking with the Little Bird gunship impossible while yawing uncontrollably. - mouse aiming of weapons is not smooth, making precision fire more difficult than it should be. - graphics don't feel modern -- there is a lot of obvious stippling or dithering on most textures.  - the much bragged about first person camera mode lacks an aim-down-sight feature.  Finally I have to say this plays more like a $30 title; $60 is a real robbery vice a PC game one. Grudgingly checking 'yes.'

TL;DR I purchased GTA 5 on PS3 winter 2013, played for a year, pre-purchased it on Steam, and you're still reading this?  Seriously, my gripes about this game are few, and I won't even bother listing all the positive things because I'd probably leave something out.    Online mode is usually a bunch of immature players who think FPS games are for killing all other players. So I just keep to myself and don't let anyone get too close or risk getting bombed, sniped, etc.     There is also some cheating that takes place in online but Rockstar has very low tolerance for cheaters and a built in reporting system.     The jobs in online can get a little repetitive. By jobs I mean contact missions, partly because they have the best story base and partly because you'll find out who can cooperate with others to reach a common goal pretty quickly. It'll take you four hours, at level 82 because contact missions unlock over time, to play through the missions that don't require special equipment or mics for complex organization.     The wait time in lobbies can be brutal, especially when trying to get people together for a heist.     I'm still waiting for Rockstar to release a DLC with buyable mansions, because I really envy all the nice houses in 'Rockford Hills' ~ Beverly Hills.  My issues are with Online and not Story mode, which is pretty awesome.

The wait for this to arrive on PC was not only well worth it but the extra time the developers took is noticable throughout. Even the PS4 and XB1 versions pale in comparison to this supreme version. As for the game, its simply GTA at its finest with 3 controllable characters and a beautiful city to wreak havoc in. 96/100 only because I thought Trevor was too much at times.

Despite a few port problems that myself and some friends were having, this version of GTA very much so lives up to the hype. That being said, I do have a few gripes with the single player campaign:  The biggest one is that the money is completely and annoyingly spread out. 1M is quite a bit in GTA, but not nearly enough to start snatching up buildings and buying nice cars, and past the first heist, you'll stick around 1M until the end. This can make the game seem a bit annoying, as more often than not you have no incentives (other than story) to continue playing the main storyline. There's very little money to be made until the end, and the side quests don't give you much to build on either.  Other than that, it is a great game, and well worth the money, especially if you liked previous GTAs, but I don't think I'll be replaying it anytime soon.

Alright, before continuing any further into my review, let me say this. In this review, I won't be referring to rockstars greed or anything of that nature, i'm reviewing the game, not the company.  Anyways, lets begin, This game is my absolute favorite game of all time. I remember being a huge fan of GTA IV and playing it daily, and I can recall the second I heard about GTA V. I was immidately hyped, there was no stopping my hype train. I was wondering how they could possibly top the greatness of GTA IV....  oh, oh they did, by a long shot!  When I launched this game for the first time, I had a feeling I can't even describe. No game will ever make me feel the way GTA V did. This game is an absolute masterpiece.   The graphics, of course, are amazing. The vehicle handling is profoundly better than that of GTA IV's. It feels like more of a racing game, more than some clunky, drifty, unbearable madness like GTA IV.  The options are endless: Want to rob a liquor store? Check Want to race your friends? Check Want to pull off a heist? Check Want to fly a giant ♥♥♥ C130 around and try and dive-bomb other players? Check Want to stand on a harrier and go up into the stratosphere and have one of your friends land a helicopter on the jet? CHECK!   I think you get the point.  If there is ANY, and I mean, ANY inclination of you getting this game, i'd say go for it, this game is worth every dime. Not only that but I don't see this game dying out anytime soon, they're always adding new, free, DLC to online mode to keep things fresh. The most recent one being a low-rider update where you can even install HYDRAULICS!   Anyways, get this game, you WILL NOT regret it.

It's a great, well made game that's clearly had a lot of time put into by people who know what they are doing. The campaign is a good mixture of funny and enticing, and I'm looking forward to putting more time into the single player. Despite this, it's not the best GTA ever made. I personally prefer the style of the other GTA's (San Andreas comes to mind) where you only play as one character, as I believe you feel more connected to that character as they go through a story line. It wouldn't have been the same if you could actually play as Ryder, or Wu Zi back in the day.  The online is great fun, the first few days of playing it with my friends was nothing but hilarious, however once the excitement passes and you need something 'more' to keep you playing, I feel GTA V falls behind other somewhat similar games such as Altis Life on Arma 3. First of all, as someone who preordered, I received enough money as a gift to buy the best appartment and one of the best cars. After doing a few heists, I could then afford the best car. Umm, now what? Mindless races and missions are fun for a while, but it could be so much better if there was more to spend your money on. Barely a month after the game came out and I haven't wanted to play online for a while.  Overall, I can see why many people love this game, and definately recommend you to try it.

For those who have a problem with unpacking. In my case I have a 120 GB SSD... (formatted, no OS)  That not enough for this game unpacking.  First, Let it unpack until it pop up and error. Then looking for an unpacked file in Download folder.  Select some unpacked files and move it to another drive (in my case I'm moving sfx folder that worth around 16 GB)  When it moved, try unpacking again. It will begin on where your left off.  When unpacking finished it will back to 60 something GB. Move folder back to Common/[Game folder]/[Wherever It will be in the first place] this will be a little tricky cause it may not in a same position before you move it from Download folder.  Doing file check... let it download if necessary.  Work and PLAY! : )  *If you have more space please do some backup before, Just for sure.  For a game and 10 minutes in it...  20/10 : )

Not a perfect game, but certainly the best of its genre. Recently this title has been suffering from what appears to be poor decisions on the part of the developers. Many have complained about poor performance after updates when they had fantastic performance previously. I, myself, have only had one instance where my experience dipped into the 'poor quality' category. Other than that I've had a blast with this game. If your computer meets the minimum requirements, I'd see about buying this game. A word of advice - As soon as you're out of the tutorial, focus on finding a fast car and break some laws so you become wanted by the police. A higher the wanted level is ideal for this. That way, you'll see as soon as possible if your computer will struggle with framerate drops, popping textures or anything of the like. Police chases are considered to be one of the most prominent areas where these issues occur. If you're able to get to this point and see for yourself if you are able to play within the first few hours of having the game running, then it won't be too late to ask for a full refund if you need it.  That being said, I put over 200 hours into this game just on PC and still highly recommend Grand Theft Auto V/Online for its replayability, open-world sandbox style and engaging characters throughout the entire story.

Pros -Massive and detailed open world to explore. I've been playing this game for two years on last gen and current gen and I still keep finding new stuff in San Andreas. -Controls are responsive, even when using kb+m. Also one of the best keyboard driving controls I've ever experienced. Would suggest to tweak the plane controls though when you are using a keyboard. -One of the best console ports I've ever played on PC. Rockstar did a good job optimizing this game for PC.  Cons -The story is IMO not on par with previous GTA suchs as GTA IV and GTA SA. In comparison to IV, the story is a little bit short and simple but feels like it was rushed whereas IV had a fully developed and complex storyline. The story is still good though. -Fewer side missions compared to previous GTA. While the S&F missions kind of helped with the post game content, I was a bit disappointed that the side missions were mostly races and property missions. Heck, the property missions doesn't even work properly and glitches out on most of my playthroughs. -GTAO is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of grinding and game breaking mods.

GTAV is a fantastic game on PC, really well optimized, but, does have its issues(which I've listen below) which I hope Rockstar will fix in the future.  Issues: Texture/Model Pop-in (There is a workaround by setting the GTAV.exe process in task manager to High Priority)  Shadow draw distance issues (only renders high quality shadows at a very low distance.)  Some stuttering issues (Workaround as well, at least for Nvidia[dont know about AMD] by setting the max pre-rendered frames to 1 in the Nvidia Control Panel or Nvidia Inspector)  Other than the stated issues above, GTAV its amazingly well done, highly recommend! This is a monumental achievement in gaming. Not only does it look like a brand new game, but it launched without a hitch. The industry needs to study under Rockstar's coders, because this game is so well optimized that it makes recent AAA releases look damn embarassing. This is without a doubt, one of the greatest games ever created.  ______ Gameplay + Almost 100% a completely succesful port. + The mouse control for Airplanes and Helicopters is surprisingly succesful once you get used to it. + The First Person view is also splendidly well integrated and fun to switch in and out of. - I still found myself wanting to play this with a gamepad, because it does have it's spikes of difficulty where auto aim toggling/target toggling + Modible cars and bikes. Although I wish the default cars for each character were able to be changed. Some aspects of the modibiltiy leave a little be desired and seem to be more cosmetic than functional. + Character stats that improve with usage. Always a + to have a little RPG element to an action game. - This causes me to drive Motorcycles at top speeds againsts 3 lanes of highway traffic to level up Driving. Like Trinity.  Graphics + Amazingly gorgeous improvement from the PS3/XBOX version. HD textures FTW. + Features like NVIDIA TXAA, PCSS, Ambient Occlusion, Depth of Field are well implemented. + Incredibly well coded and optimized to run well on high settings with an average machine. - No PhysX :(. Then again, if taking apart a house bullet by bullet, shingle by shingle and plank by plank were possible in this game like the excellent Mafia II - I would probably never be able to tear myself from it.  Story + I never really thought much of GTA's previous storys; but Rockstar knocks it out of the park. With a capability to be both silly and crass, and still have you feel a connection to each of the 3 main guys. Particularly with Michael. + Long game. Love long storys. Lots of character development over a long period of time.  + Heists!  Sound/Voice Acting + Incredible level of detail in the writing of dialogue. It is equally performed as such by the actors.  Extra Stuff + There is an essentially endless amount of extras and exploration and easter eggs to deal with if your into that. + Can't wait for the mod community to do what they do. Some more HUD/UI customizability for starters  The State of My Well Being + This game is the purest crack rock one could ever light up. - My skin is slowly fusing to my chair from video game addiction.  ?:)

Grand Theft Auto V is a masterpiece. The story of the game is thrilling, easily followable and very developed. Along with the developed character structure and impecable voice acting, its also really fun and enjoyable. Player choice adds a great level of depth to the game and the open world is pushing the entire industry forward. Rockstar left nothing untouched in this amazing world, the level of detail is unmatched and very well done. Although it originally was a problem, Rockstar has done a great job patching the engine and allowing GTA V to run on less powerful systems while maintaining an amazing graphical standard. This is the only game I have ever bought full price, and I don't regret it. This game deserves every penny of the price. Rockstars constant updates also keep the community and the content thriving. Overall GTA V is one of my favorite games, and it reflects what I look for and anticipate in every game I review. It serves as a model for what publishers, and what the industry needs to live up to. If Grand Theft Auto V defines the future of gaming, I am excited.  10/10

EDIT: A sectioned #/10 review for different sections of the game is at the bottom, for your convenience.  ----  A great game to play with friends.  It's a truly immersive sandbox with great mods, great physics, and so much detail it routinely blows my mind. Almost every day I play it I discover some new little thing that blows my mind and makes me feel like I'm playing the game for the first time again. Saying it's perfect would be lying, but it's probably the best game in the series yet.  -----  Gameplay: Everything feels fluid in this game. The world truly feels big without being so ridiculously large that you despise the thought of travelling from one end to the other. Cars handle well. New details, both immersive and otherwise, packed absolutely everywhere. Honestly, when I think of this game I think of fantastic gameplay.  10/10   Graphics/Visual Experience: The level of attention paid to detail in this game is absurd, bordering on Kojima levels at times. A lot of these are gameplay details but I'm putting it in the visual experience section because a lot of it goes on around you without your player affecting anything. The graphics are great already, but if they're not to your liking there are tons of realism mods out there to keep you satisfied. This is another area in which Rockstar's ability to create an atmosphere really shines through.  9/10   Sound: Guns lack a bassy sound, but when the rest of the world is made so perfectly noisy, I'm willing to overlook such a misstep. Radio stations are better than ever, and Self Radio makes driving fun if you don't like the stations already in the game.  7.75/10   Replayability: This is a game that's replayable because it's versatile. I've booted up this game because I've wanted to race, because I wanted to play a biking game, because I wanted to shoot things, because I wanted to explore an open world. It does all of these and does them all equally well. For the moment this is one of the most replayable games I have in my library.  10/10   How it Runs: Quite demanding. It's not necessarily poorly optimized, it just seems that R* is so focused on maintaining a visually impressive game that they don't want to offer too many options to crank it down.

'Obvious Console Port'  I wanted this game to live up to the hype; in some way its does, but major issues exist.  Pros: - it was finally released on PC? - largeish sandbox area to explore, or is it? Somehow it feels smaller than the San Andreas title's map. - there are no locked areas; you can drive around immediately (compare to Vice City's locked bridges)  Cons: - joystick support (which worked in Vice City) is lacking, and the keyboard+mouse controls make attacking with the Little Bird gunship impossible while yawing uncontrollably. - mouse aiming of weapons is not smooth, making precision fire more difficult than it should be. - graphics don't feel modern -- there is a lot of obvious stippling or dithering on most textures.  - the much bragged about first person camera mode lacks an aim-down-sight feature.  Finally I have to say this plays more like a $30 title; $60 is a real robbery vice a PC game one. Grudgingly checking 'yes.'

I will split the review into 2 sections: Story Mode and Online.  Story Mode Rating: 9/10 Online Rating: 7/10   Story Mode Pro: - Needless to say, the envrionment, AI engine, object varieties, mini games, songs are awesome. - Lots of side quests and random encounters with very interesting funny dialodges, won't be feeling repetative at all. - Each playable character with detailed background and development. Players will like them more as the game progress. - Good endings based on player's choice.  Story Mode Cons: - Very few heists in the story mode and only available based on story progression. - You will only get rich at the end of the game, in which in kinda meaningless. - Very few attires, acessories, cars and hairstyles selection in story mode.  Story Mode Overall: One of the best game of the year. Worth to play and spend time for the story.   Online Mode Pro: - It's free!  - A lot of heists, good story progression.  - A lot of attires, acessories, cars and hairstyles  Online Mode Con: - Time consuming. You have to WAIT ♥♥♥♥♥ LONG just to enter a session, quit a session, join a heist, and the heist fail if 1 player quit, then wait to enter another session. IT'S ALL WAITING ONLY. - Many idiots - Weapons and cars unlocked based on player level, unless you willing to spend real cash.   Online Mode Overall: Would recomend you find friends of 4 and enter a private session.

GTAV is a fantastic game on PC, really well optimized, but, does have its issues(which I've listen below) which I hope Rockstar will fix in the future.  Issues: Texture/Model Pop-in (There is a workaround by setting the GTAV.exe process in task manager to High Priority)  Shadow draw distance issues (only renders high quality shadows at a very low distance.)  Some stuttering issues (Workaround as well, at least for Nvidia[dont know about AMD] by setting the max pre-rendered frames to 1 in the Nvidia Control Panel or Nvidia Inspector)  Other than the stated issues above, GTAV its amazingly well done, highly recommend!  Specs:  i5 2500k @ 3.7ghz EVGA GTX 680 2GB 32GB DDR3 RAM

I bought this game when it was released back in 2013 for PS3 and Xbox360. I played a'lot of online and a little bit of singleplayer. I enjoy online the most I think its what makes this game great being able to access the entire map and do whatever you please. Now that I own a decent gaming laptop, the graphics are gorgeous and vivid. I am playing at 900p and getting about 35-40 fps. Back on ps3 the graphics are unbearable and I don't know how my eyes got used to the frames. I haven't noticed any pop in whatsoever (coming from a regular 5400rpm 1TB HDD user). There is a bit of jaggies and stuttering but I have it under control when I set up maximum pre rendered frames to ''1'' in my nvidia control papnel and power management to maximum performance. I would reccomend this game to anyone it is truely amazing how Rockstar developed this game allowing those with not very good specs to play this game even at normal settings the game still looks BEAUTIFUL. Spectacular Open World game in which contains ALOT of features which is outstanding within the GTA Series as it adds more features than ever before.  Grand Theft Auto 5 is the story of Three criminals and their way to get a living through their shenanigans. Micheal is the rich man who has a broken family with a lazy son, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ daughter and cheatin wife, he regrets leaving the bank heist days, he has the special ability to activate Bullet Time. Franklin is the new guy to the crime group as he is an expert with cars, his special ability is to slow down time when driving for faster turns. Finally, Trevor who is the old friend hyper-Pansexual who is wild and crazy to be around, his special ability is a rage mode in which he deals more and takes less damage.  In this game you follow their story and make some choices through the way, there are too many features to talk about in a simple review but there is alot like owning businesses, houses, cars, jets, boats/submarines and interact with minigames around the world.  There is an Online mode of the game in which you can play the same activities and more with others online and can also create your own character and traits. Singleplayer is a great load of fun and tons more fun can be had playing online. this truely is game of the year.

After playing the game for almost 150 hours now, I feel I have put enough time in to review it fairly, so here goes. I'll start with the good: It's the GTA that I know and love. It feels more like San Andreas than like GTA 4 to me, which is a good thing since I adored SA for its open space and variety, and felt like 4 (despite being a solid game) just doesn't live up to the legacy. GTA 5 has a well-written and interesting single-player experience: the playable characters are diverse and interact well with each other; the mission are entertaining and numerous. Probably the thing that interested me most about this iteration of GTA was the native support for multi-player (finally!) with its Online Mode. In it, players can join friends, crew (think 'clan') or strangers in session of (I believe) up to 30 players. The online version of the game is rich in Rockstar-created activities, and the mission creator allows for a great deal of additional variety. You can race, fight, arm-wrestle, play tennis, contend for resources and do a whole host of other activities with fellow criminals.  Recently, I spend most of my gaming time in GTA Online, and I feel that it really is a great addition to the game. Despite this, it has its ups & downs. There are several key issues I should address here: - Hackers - Mission requirements and player dependency - Loading times So, hackers. What do I mean? One moment you're cruising around with a friend, taking on the world and feeling its the best game ever. The next you're violently exploded by a hacker from half the map away. All your weapons are suddenly gone. You open the menu to hit to hit 'change session' but you can't even do that, since THE GAME CLOSES THE MENU EVERY TIME YOU DIE. Sure, you can report them by email. Sure, hacks are transient and eventually the game should grow 'safer' and less exploitable as Rockstar addresses issues and releases patches... but right now, some days are just bad like that. What's that about mission requirements? Well, to me the best kind of missions in GTA Online are the heists. These require a 4-person team to play. So sometimes you're in the swing of things, running with a solid crew and clearing out mission-after-mission... and sometimes you're just stuck in eternal lobby-limbo, waiting for that elusive 'last member' to join your team, and every time you get one they quit mid-mission (throwing you all out, since that's how the game is designed). This might not be a problem if you're not going after heists with such enthusiasm, but eventually you have to remember one thing: Multi-player games are just that - meant for multiple people to play together, and your fellow players will make-or-break your experience with the game, almost every time. Keep that in mind, and if you have a big group of friends who are already into the game - good for you! And finally, loading times. I got a fairly high end PC and I can run the game on very high settings without performance issues, and still I spend a good 2-3 minutes loading into the game at start-up, and a minute or two after every mission. This is time consuming, it breaks the immersion, and mainly just sucks because sometimes the game initiates loading in cases where it really shouldn't have. I'll give you an example that happens to me daily: You're invited to a mission while playing online. You hit 'accept' and instantly get a message saying 'session full, returning to GTA online'... so far so good - too bad you were in-session literally 3 seconds ago, and now you're going to load up another one for 2 minutes. Done loading? What's that, another invite? 'Heh, let's try' you say... Nope. Full again. Loading again. Enjoy your wait. This issue might not be that bad if you're running the game off an SSD, but then again, it's a 60 GB game. Kinda heavy, IMO.  TL;DR? I got you covered. Good: Great looking game. Very solid single-player. Online mode is a beast, especially when you have friends online. Bad: Some bugs ruin missions, though rarely. Hackers online. Game aka 'Loading Simulator 2015.' Final verdict: Very Recommended!  Thanks for taking the time to read my review. Obviously all the above is just my opinion, and I appreciate anyone who cares enough to read it. The ultimate version of GTAV!  I've already played the heck out of this game on PS3...beaten the story and played MP...everyone pretty much knows that this is a great game chock full of goodness in an open world scenario.  The PC does the consoles one better with glorious HD graphics with low system requirements. My experience thus far on PC has been smooth as buttah with zero hiccups or flaws.  My rig is not even high end, and the only current thing I have in it my graphics card. Regardless, I'm able to crank out a smooth 50 to 60FPS in all but the most intensive scenes where it drops to 40FPS occasionally using max settings.  i7-920 24GB Crucial Ram EVGA X58 SLi EVGA GTX 780 Ti Black 2TB WD Black HD 1920x1080Rez Max All Settings (3GB VRAM used)  The added improvements are what make this the ultimate version. I spent an hour of the 4 hours playing so far just screwing around in Director Mode. It is so much with basically built in cheats to let you be the fanatic you've always dreamed about. Doing massive jumps and crazy crashes just to record the best scenes you can make. There's no doubt there are going to be some impressive videos coming out soon.  To keep this short, Rockstar did a commendable job on this game, and the port is lovingly done. A huge difference from GTAIV's release, it's obvious they paid attention. Yes, there are teething problems, but overall this game is worth the money and your investment. It will provide absolutely hours of entertainment. Just wait for the mods!

mods are not allowed in multiplayer mods are not allowed in MULTIPLAYER mods are NOT ALLOWED IN MULTIPLAYER MODS ARE NOT ALLOWED IN MULTIPLAYERRRRRRRRRRRRRR If you use ANY kind of modification to grand theft auto online, you WILL be banned WITHOUT QUESTION. This has been stated multiple times, and has been stated that you will NOT BE BANNED FOR USING MODS IN SINGLEPLAYER!  Clear? Clear. On with the review!  I won't be going over the main game, because you already know how good it is. Grand Theft Auto V, the fast-paced crime simulator made by the incredible Rockstar Games finally comes to PC in what is considered the definitive edition of the game, and for good reason. 60FPS and 4k support changes the game so much, along with mouse & keyboard support. Aiming is much easier. The new Rockstar Editor feature allows you to record, edit, and upload clips of your random adventures in Los Santos. Directly related is Director Mode, which allows you to set conditions and change the environment of the world, and make amazing videos filled with action, and set music of your choice. Mods make the PC version the best part of the game without question: Bored? Spawn a Hydra and go flying around the map, as a monkey, and make it rain whales and enable carmageddon and have cars explode and fly around like an eagle on bath salts. As said before, be warned- Remove any and ALL modifications to the base games before going into Grand Theft Auto Online, because you WILL be banned for cheating online. Again, ANY and EVERY SINGLE MOD. Even FOV will get you banned. Although this is hated by many, it is to prevent cheaters. The 18 month wait for the 4K bluray uber version of this game has been well worth it. The single player element, while being an exact replica of the original, brings to life in ultra HD a game world so meticulously crafted, it's almost miraculous. It generally makes Watch Dogs look a bit bland.  Having played the story once, but not finishing on xbox 360 brings a familiar feeling of course while playing this version, and there are missions in this that i didn't really want to play through again, but the addition of the first person view adds a whole new dimension to things. Being face to face with the game world immerses the player wonderfully and what an awesomely vivid place it is. Textures pop, books on bookshelves have readable spines, signs in shops aren't simply blobs of colour..everything is there to be read and in first person mode, it's in your face. It's certainly not an afterthought mode either, the game works fluidly in this mode and everything just works as if it was meant to be played that way. It's no user mod.  The settings pages scream 'PC VERSION' with everything you could possibly want adjustable, there to be adjusted. The overhaul to the lighting and effects has brought gaming a contender for the most beautiful game of the decade. It's just ♥♥♥♥ing nuts. It's a sandbox I don't want to leave any time soon. 10/10

Excellent port. It has everything that you would want for a good PC port. I have a GTX 660 Ti, I get 60 FPS 80% of the time on high settings, when it drops - it only drops to about 45 (rarely 30). I completed on console & I love the story, one of my favourite games of all time.

So far so good, after taking awhile to unpack anyway (to be expected).  1440p max everything including all options under advanced settings and I'm getting between 45 and 60 fps at all times in the city (haven't been to the desert just yet) on a GTX 980 with a light OC and i7-2600K with 8gb memory. No AA though, frames drop to mid 40's with 2x.  The game is gorgeous, those saying it's not are either butthurt about a technical issue or seriously need their eyes checked. It's absolutely night and day from both console versions (I played both PS ones). Everything from improved lighting, tessellation, AO, vastly improved shadows and shaders, the works, is inlcuded, and all very customizable.  GIve it a go!

I've got a pretty up to date system, so I don't know how much that's to credit.  But I've had basically no trouble aside from installing it during the launch day/hour rush.  It's quite enjoyable with a 360 controller as well.
